questions.text: 1. An 8-year-old boy has been limping painlessly for 10 months. Given the provided X-ray, what's the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an 8-year-old boy limping painlessly for 10 months, with the X-ray showing a fragmented head of the left femur, suggests the probable diagnosis to be Perthes disease.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-9 years. The incidence is higher in boys than in girls.

It is usually a unilateral disease, but can occur bilaterally in 10% of cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.

The disease is characterised by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head, resulting in osteonecrosis and the cessation of bone growth. The lateral epiphyseal artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone, which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates on doing any activity and is relieved by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip, and abduction with internal rotation is limited.

X-ray findings depend on the stages 

* Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus

* Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis

* Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase

* Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The radiograph below shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.



Other options:

Option A: DDH (Developmental dysplasia of the hip) is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen.



Option B: SCFE (Slipped capital femoral epiphysis) presents in early adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin or knee. In a normal hip, Klein’s line intersects the epiphysis, but failure to do so results in a positive Trethowan sign and indicates a slip.



Option D: TB hip is a painful condition that can lead to limb shortening, as shown in the X-ray below.

questions.text: 2. A 20-year-old man presents with chronic back pain. The pain is worse in the morning and reduces with physical activity within 1.5 hours. He has a history of anterior uveitis. The X-ray of the sacroiliac joint was normal. On examination, lumbar lordosis was lost, and spinal flexion was reduced. What is the diagnostic modality for early diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ankylosing Spondylitis. The diagnostic modality for early diagnosis of this condition is MRI of the sacroiliac joint.

MRI of the sacroiliac joint allows detailed investigation of the sacroiliac joints, and may show typical erosions and features of inflammation, such as bone oedema.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of seronegative spondyloarthritis (Rheumatoid factor negative) characterised by early morning stiffness and backache, which improves with exercise. The majority of the patients who suffer from ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive. Extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

X-ray spine shows fused vertebrae looking like a bamboo tree (bamboo spine), which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis. Other clinical features are loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and diminished spinal movements.



X-ray findings:

* Erosion of sacroiliac joints- earliest sign

* Periarticular sclerosis in later stages 

* Squaring of vertebrae due to the flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change

* Bamboo spine appearance due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae

* Wedging of the vertebra leading to hyperkyphosis



Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

Other options:

Opton A: X-ray of the Dorsolumbar spine will not be able to show features of inflammation very clearly, and X-ray of the sacroiliac joint has already been done in the patient.

Option B: Anti-CCP antibodies are tested in patients suspected of Rheumatoid arthritis.

Option C: CT of the sacroiliac joint also helps in identifying changes, but MRI is more sensitive.

questions.text: 3. A 68-year-old female presents with chronic lower back pain. The X-ray spine is as follows. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic lower back pain and X-ray spine showing forward shift of the upper part of the spinal column (L5) on the stable vertebra below (S1), and elongation of the arch of the spine, suggests the diagnosis to be Spondylolisthesis.

Spondylolisthesis is a condition where there is forward displacement of one vertebra over the one beneath it, most often seen in L5 over S1. It usually presents with backache and sometimes with sciatica. Symptoms worsen on standing or walking. It is usually asymptomatic and is detected on a routine X-ray taken during screening.

On examination, there may be a visible or palpable step (step sign) above the sacral crest due to the forward displacement of the spinal column along with increased lumbar lordosis.

The Scottie-dog sign/ Scottish terrier dog sign is a sign used to describe a normal oblique view of the dorsolumbar spine. On an oblique view, the pars interarticularis area of the vertebra appears like a Scottish dog. Whenever there is a fracture or other abnormality in the pars interarticularis, this dog is abnormal. If the Scottish dog appears to be beheaded, with a large distance between the "head" and the "body" of the dog, it is suggestive of spondylolisthesis. 

The image below shows a beheaded Scottish dog :





Below is an image of a normal Scottish dog sign:



Other options:

Option A: If the Scottish dog appears to be wearing a collar, then it is a defect in the pars interarticularis, namely spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is a condition in which there is a break in the pars interarticularis, usually seen in the L5 lumbar vertebra. An image of a Scottish dog wearing a collar is shown below:





Option B: Klippel feil syndrome- There is a congenital short and stiff neck due to fused or deformed cervical vertebrae.



Option C: Crushed vertebrae are usually seen in fractures.

questions.text: 4. A 65-year-old man presents with a bony lesion in the lower limb. He also gives a history of an increase in hat size. On examination, bones feel warm to the touch and bowing of the leg is present. X-ray showed a mixed lytic-sclerotic bone lesion. ALP levels-250 IU/L, Normal- serum calcium, phosphate and PTH. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the likely diagnosis to be Paget's disease of bone.

Paget's disease is characterised by increased osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone turnover. This causes localised sites of lysis and excavations in bone. This is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone because of increased osteoblastic activity. The internal architecture is abnormal, and the bone is unusually brittle. Raised levels of plasma alkaline phosphatase are seen. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal.

Deformities are usually seen in the lower limbs. Bending of long bones occurs due to mechanical stress. The tibia bows anteriorly and the femur anterolaterally. The limb looks bent and feels thick, and the skin is unduly warm. This is known as osteitis deformans. If the skull is affected, it enlarges, and the patient gives a history of an increase in hat size. The skull base can also become flattened, giving the appearance of a short neck.

The radiological signs seen are:

* Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion of the involved bone.

* Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull

* Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

The image shows a cotton wool appearance of the skull seen in Paget's disease.



Tam o'Shanter hat sign in skull radiograph resembling the Scottish Tam o'Shanter hat.



Other options:

Option B: Primary Hyperparathyroidism is caused by increased parathyroid hormone. It causes osteoclastic resorption of bone, leading to raised calcium levels and complications of hypercalcemia like renal stones, abdominal pain, and depression. Subperiosteal resorption of the phalanges is a diagnostic feature of hyperparathyroidism. The X-ray skull shows a salt-and-pepper appearance, as shown in the image below.



Option C: Osteomalacia: The classical lesion is the Looser zone, a thin transverse band of rarefaction in a normal-looking bone. These zones occur due to incomplete stress fractures, which heal with callus lacking in calcium. Raised levels of alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone can be seen.

The image below shows the Looser zone:



Option D: Metastatic disease of the bone presents with pain, swelling, pathological fracture, spinal cord compression and hypercalcaemia. The lesions can be osteoblastic or osteolytic.

Pearl PM0655: Pathological fracture

Pathological fractures occur with normal stresses in the bones that have been weakened by a change in its structure or through a lytic lesion.

Factors suggestive of a pathologic fracture:

* Fracture after minor trauma

* Pain at the site before the fracture

* Multiple recent fractures

* History of primary malignancy

Causes:

1. Generalized bone disease: 

* Osteoporosis

* Metabolic bone diseases

* Osteogenesis imperfecta

* Paget's disease

* Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia

* Myelomatosis

2. Local benign conditions:

* Chronic infection

* Solitary bone cyst

* Aneurysmal bone cyst

* Chondroma

3. Primary malignant tumors:

* Chondrosarcoma

* Osteosarcoma

* Ewing's tumor

4. Metastatic tumors

* Mets from breast, lung, kidney, thyroid, colon and prostate

questions.text: 5. A 20 year old male athlete while playing football, has an eversion injury, which ligament is most commonly injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an ankle fracture with deltoid ligament injury. 

The deltoid ligament, or medial collateral ligament, is a strong triangular band attached to the apex, the anterior and posterior borders of the medial malleolus. It has 2 layers, superficial and deep. The superficial layer consists of tibionavicular fibres anteriorly, tibiocalcaneal fibres in the middle, and superficial posterior tibiotalar fibres posteriorly. Deep layer consists of anterior tibiotalar fibres, tibiocalcaneal in the middle and deep posterior tibiotalar posteriorly.

It is primarily responsible for maintaining stability on the medial aspect of the ankle. The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilises the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are seen when the ankle undergoes an unstable ankle fracture or eversion. 

The image given below shows the ligaments attached to the medial side of the ankle.



The anterior talofibular ligament is most commonly injured with inversion sprains. Important ligaments of the ankle present on the lateral side (lateral collateral ligament), and therefore likely to be injured in inversion sprains, include:

* Anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) 

* Posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL)

* Calcaneofibular ligament (CFL)

questions.text: 6. A 30 year old man presents to the emergency department following a motorbike accident and is found to have a closed fracture of the shaft of tibia. Six hours later, he develops severe leg pain which was not relieved by analgesics and worsend on passive dorsiflexion of the foot. On examination, sensations over the first dorsal webspace were lost, but dorsalis pedis pulsations were present. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Elevate the limb and give Opiod analgesics

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated with Emergency Fasciotomy.

In compartment syndrome, ischaemia occurs at the level of capillaries, so pulses may still be felt and the skin may not be pale. The earliest feature is severe pain or a bursting sensation.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

* Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 

* Paresthesia 

* Pallor

* Paralysis

* Pulselessness

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed. Only splitting the plaster is not helpful, and the limb must be kept flat. This is because elevating the limb causes a further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates muscle ischemia.

In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, fasciotomy should be performed. This involves opening all four compartments via medial and lateral incisions. Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later. If tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured, but if there is muscle necrosis, debridement needs to be carried out.

The image below shows a fasciotomy.



Pearl PM2207: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 



 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: 7. An elderly patient presents with a painful right knee with no history of trauma. On synovial fluid analysis, there are rhomboid-shaped crystals seen and positive birefringence on polarised light. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image of positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals with a painful knee are suggestive of pseudogout.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD) that trigger an acute inflammatory reaction within the joint. It predominantly affects the elderly. Knee, wrist, shoulder and ankle are the most commonly affected joints. There is swelling and pain, which may become severe over 6–24 hours. Fever may also be present.

Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage that are positively birefringent is diagnostic of pseudogout.



Other options :

Option A: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease. It occurs in old age, mainly in the weight-bearing joints like the knee and hip. There is a narrowing of the joint space of the affected joint.

Option C: Gouty arthritis is caused by the deposition of sodium urate crystals, which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent. The image below shows needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals in gout.



Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory joint disease. It presents with symmetrical polyarthritis and tenosynovitis, morning stiffness, elevation of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and the appearance of autoantibodies (rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies).

questions.text: 8. A male comes to the casualty after an RTA with a midshaft fracture of the femur and undergoes surgery. In the ward, 2 days later, the patient presented with breathlessness, tachycardia, confusion and petechial rashes over the chest and conjunctival haemorrhage. What's the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with breathlessness, tachycardia, confusion and petechial rashes over the chest and conjunctival haemorrhage 2 days after a surgery for midshaft fracture of the femur after an RTA suggests the probable diagnosis to be Fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after the fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. Its pathogenesis can be related to 2 factors:

* The release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats causes toxic vasculitis.

* Actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

The early signs of fat embolism syndrome that occur within 72 hours of injury are fever and tachycardia. The presenting features can be classified into 2 types:

* Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation, and coma

* Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia

Petechial rashes can be seen on the front of the neck, anterior axillary fold, chest, and conjunctiva.

Other options:

Option A: DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) will present with thrombosis and bleeding.

Option B: Sepsis will present with fever, tachycardia, and hypovolemia.

Option D: Pulmonary embolism presents with a sudden onset of dyspnoea and usually occurs due to deep vein thrombosis.

Pearl PM1500: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria

* Petechial rash

* Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes

* CNS depression.

Minor criteria

* Tachycardia

* Pyrexia

* Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)

* Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)

* Acute thrombocytopenia

* Acute decrease in hemoglobin

* Fat globules in sputum

* Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.
